Fun fact about the 9 thing: you can clearly visualize how it works by starting at ten and going to nineteen. So, for ten it’s 10-(1+0)=9. For eleven, it’s 11-(1+1)=9. No matter what you do, the subtraction of the two numbers, as a consequence of our understanding of mathematics, will always get you to nine or a multiple thereof. Realistically there could be infinite fixed points if you declare your end goal to be any multiple of nine.

Tl;dr, mathematics is weird but also super cool!

It's interesting that the last 'FOUR' trick doesn't work the same way in Ukrainian language

We have only one number that is spelled with the same number of letters that it represents - 3 ('Три' in Ukrainian, three letters)

But if you choose, for example, number 10 this will lead to 6-5-4 loop:
10 -> Десять -> 6 -> Шість -> 5 -> П'ять -> 4 -> Чотири -> 6 -> Шість -> 5 -> П'ять -> 4 -> Чотири -> 6 -> ... and so on

So in Ukrainian this procedure is idempotent only for some cases and for other it's not... or is it still idempotent, but rather than stuck at 3-loop you become stuck in 6-5-4 loop? And is there any other result for this procedure in Ukrainian? I don't know, but looks like there's not

With the 5x5 pixel picture I think I found a way to have every pixel outside of it's original spot without having any pixels outside of the larger picture assuming you can have perfect precision.
First shrink the picture to by 1/5 or smaller the original size and then rotate it by exactly 180 degrees then place the picture inside two pixels like lets say the orange and white two so as in the small orange and white are on the border or the large pair which means even though technically the small white borders large white it is not inside the large white pixel which is the same for the two orange pixels as well.
Of course my method only works if you have literally perfect rotation and placement, but assuming you aren't bothered with the colors touching the border, it technically works as a way to have no pixels in their original spot.

So, the temperature thing...I don't understand. You're speaking a though a person can simply traverse the earth and get to the opposite side immediately or at least quickly. But in reality two people could travel exactly opposite each other and not have a temperatures that meet.

Let's say that one person has a temperature of 60 degrees and the other 80. One could conceivably follow a cold front and stay in temps that stay below 60 while the other has weather that ensures that the temperature stays above 80.

Hence, when they get to their respective opposites from where they started they never crossed temperatures. The place that was 60 in now 80 and the place that was 80 is now 60.

So, I suppose that if you had a way to travel so quickly as to negate the possibility it would be axiomatic, but I don't know of any travel that absolutely rules out this scenario

If you want proof of this, well in Japanese the loops are different from english, and they can even be different depending on how you write the numbers.

First loop:
2 = に (ni)
1 = いち (ichi)
...
You oscillate between these two forever.
Although if you use romaji (representing the sound with Roman letters) you instead loop at 3 (san) since it contains the amount of letters it represents, when romanized.
and if you use Kanji then you loop at 1 since most numbers in kanji are represented by one character.

If you speak another language as a second language, please tell me about the loop in your language

I watched this a few years ago and never since, but ever since, I have though about what if there is a break in the continuum of temperature and pressure? Like what if there are two molecules or rows of molecules of the atmosphere adjacent to each other that have distinctly different temperatures or pressures?

That awkward moment when michael Stevens invalidly assumes the continuum hypothesis

That other awkward moment when you realize the proof that at least one pair of diametrically opposite points on earth necessarily has the same temperature and pressure is invalid. Simply suppose each point on the earth has a temperature equal to its latitude and a pressure equal to its longitude. As each point thus has its own unique value, values will never be repeated. In fact, it cannot even be guaranteed that any pairs of points have the same temperature because both a sphere and a line have infinite cardinality aleph1 and therefore have a bijection between them. Map a strictly increasing number line representing temperature to the surface of the earth and again, there are no points of equivalent temperature because every point has a unique temperature.

@10:49 "The Pacific ocean is so large in fact, it contains its own antipodes"
That's true and can be found on Google Maps. Go to the Gulf of Tonkin, right click near its center, and choose Measuring Distances. Left click on some point to the east. Then zoom out of the map, and drag the second point to the pacific coasts of Peru and Chile. There you will find an area where the marked shortest distance to the Gulf of Tonkin depends very sensitively on the chosen endpoint: the distance shows west, east, north or south from there. The area is within the Pacific and contains the antipode.

That Brouwer's fixed point theorem is really interesting. The keypoint though is "continous". If Your map is discrete (e.g. consisting of pixels), You can transform it so that every point considered changes place. Let's consider a x by y map with both x and y even. If You rotate it 180° and scale it whichever You like (given both transforms are done about the map's center) the fixed point lies in the map's center which is just in the middle between the pixels.
Same goes for the coffee.
We can simplify it as fitting n balls into n positions. With sufficiently large n there's about 36.79% chance no ball repeat its position after we randomly permute the balls:

This is bullshit. After like 3 minutes of thinking I figured out how to do it, it's not very hard either.
First we rotate the board 180 deg. Then we make the board small enough to fit inside one coloured square, say for example, the grayish green one in the top right. Fit the board inside that one. But since we rotated the board 180 deg, we can now move the fight leftmost squares, being in this example the grayish green one, the yellow one, the pink one and the two grays, and fit all of those five inside the blue square next to the grayish green one. All colours are inside the grayish green one, except the grayish green one and the others, which all fit inside the blue one. False statment.

Take note that an endless cascade of Alephs is quite literally so large that it is equal to the number of Alephs before it. It contains itself.

Therefore, we can conclusively answer that due to this absolutely monstrous set of infinities being self-contained, yes. A set of all sets contains itself since there's at least one other self-contained set within it.

4 is the only number which represents the same value as the number of letters in it's name in English language is correct, but it is not the complete reason why we get stuck at 4 when doing that exercise.
In addition to this, another reason is that there is no closed loop of numbers where the value of a number is the same as the number of letters in another number in that loop, in the English language.

For example, let's say 6 is spelt as Sicks, and 5 is spelt as Faaive. Now the number of letters in 5 is 6, and in 6 is 5. So if you were to start with either of these numbers, or any other number that lead you to either of these, then you would be stuck in an endless loop of 5-6-5-6-5-6... and so on.

I was trying to make a simple terminal based calculator with C in my early days of programming and and was stumped by how to write a sqrt like function. What I ended up doing was very stupid but I was so proud of it.
float sqrt(float num, float precision) {
float root = 0;
while (root * root < num) root += precision;
return root;
}
then later at my CS bachelors I took a course "numerical computation methods" and learned about the one he showed in video and many others.

Counter argument to the coffee stirring example: as you say earlier in the video, the fixed point theorem doesn't apply when you introduce a hole.  By touching the bottom (or even side, if the contact point is submerged) of the coffee cup with the spoon, you create a hole, and the coffee topologically becomes a torus.  This invalidates the fixed point theorem for this case

@12:53 In Finnish, such a ”cosmic number” would be 5, since the Finnish word for five (”viisi”) is spelled with five letters. But there is another way to get stuck in an endless loop (a 2-loop, in this case) in Finnish, and that is between the numbers 8 and 9, since the Finnish word for eight (”kahdeksan”) is spelled with nine letters, and the Finnish word for nine (”yhdeksän”) is spelled with eight letters. 😄

Such an interesting fact about the number 4! I tried to do the same in my language to find out if we have a cosmic number but it has 2 ways of getting stuck forever: numbers with 5 letters turning to number 5 which is a 5 letter word (cinco) and numbers with 4 or 6 letters, which make a 4-6 loop (4: quatro -> 6 letters; 6: seis -> 4 letters). And by the first 20 numbers, in my native language, it’s much easier to reach a 4-6 loop than the 5 one: only the numbers 5, 13, and 20 don’t end up in a 4-6 loop

I think the coffee mug example is incorrect. We can treat a line of molecules in the center as a hole, so all the other molecules in the doughnut shape around those center molecules can move to a different place. Then, with the center molecules, we simply move that line vertically so that either the top molecule or the bottom molecule gets shifted to the opposite side of the line. If we move the line downwards, then the bottom molecule gets pushed to the top, and vice versa. Now, every molecule is in a different place and the fixed point theorem doesn't apply.

Take a toroidal shaped grouping of the liquid (that contains all of it) and rotate it around the circle defining the torroid, then rotate around the center of that circle. No points will remain fixed in place: the first rotation leaves only the points on the circle where they started, but the second rotation moves all of those points without moving any other point back to its start.

9*5 (5-1=4 and 4+5=9) 45

The Borsuk Ulum theorem seems fallacious to me, as the idea of swapping the measuring devices my moving them through space implies temporal (or an albeit a-temporal but necessarily incremental) succession.  There is nothing to imply that by the "time" we have crossed two points on the original "equal temperature" line where the pressure is the same, that the temperature has not already changed.  It seems logically necessary that for one given variable, such a line exists of equal quantities, but it does not follow that on this line there are points of identical values for other variables.  Do tell me if I've missed something here!

OK, so, the coffee one is obviously wrong because stirring is functionally equivalent to cutting (at least when you only consider the initial and final states, since it allows you to functionally remove one point from its neighbors by interposing an object between them, which object then moves one point away while allowing the others to shift and merge), so that seems to bring the act of stirring outside the scope covered by the fixed point theorem

The temperature AND pressure thing also seems wrong.

If you have take a strip, write on it a1 b2 c3 d4 e5 a5 b4 c3 d2 e1, and tape the endings together, the only place where the antipodes (identical letters) have the same number is c, and exactly c. You could write the same strip as a2 b3 c4 d5 e5 a4 b3 c2 e1 and the only antipodes with the same pressure would be in position bm and exactly c. Since you can write the strip as a12 b23 c34 and so on, it seems that at no point you will find a position where both the first and second number are identical, no matter how you slice them.

What leaves me uncertain is that this is effectively a 2-dimensional strip rather than a 3-dimensional sphere, so the math could work out for 2 independent variables over a 3-dimensional continuous space... But it's not very clear.

I hate to be the ummmmmm… Actually guy, but ummmmmm… Actually, Brouwer's fixed point theorem does not apply when stirring coffee... you are mixing the coffee in a closed container, but the fixed point theorem does not apply as the coffee is being cut and changed. sure, just by chance a particle could possibly land in the same place as it was before it started, but the theorem does not apply. (I could go on to talk about evaporation of molecules in a hot drink and how that is removing particles from the container entirely but I cannot be assed at the mo...)

Mickey, I say this with love in my heart, you're full of it in this one. The checkerboard when resized to 3/5 or smaller can be rotated to have no overlap, the map only works because it's an abstract representation and not true to life, and while at least one molecule will LIKELY find it's way back to its starting point, it's far from certain. And this would also only work in a two dimensional cup of coffee.

And the Borsuk-Ulam theorum doesn't work. It just doesn't. One molecule is a certain temperature, and the one right next to it can and will be be more than an infinitely small amount warmer or colder. Only if you measure temperature and pressure in infinitely small space will you ever find these points. On a chart they will cross, but if that chart is on a screen, odds are they will meet in between pixels. Same in the real world. On a globe with infinite detail, and infinitely accurate metrics will this work. It's a cool thought experiment, but that's all it is.

Fixed points don't exist, because points don't exist. They don't make sense. The Planc measurements imply the universe has a limited "resolution" and every single fixed point thought experiment requires impossible measurements at levels where there's nothing to measure in order to ring true. Edit: there are no continuing variables. They just can't exist. They can be imagined, but never, ever exist.

The problem I have with the Borsuk-Ulam theorem is that it assumes whatever values it is using change at a constant rate— You mentioned this very quickly in the video but neglected the fact this could tip the entire idea upside down, despite how cool I find it.
If, for example, we are using temperature as a value and we begin the process of swapping two antipodes, if one of them, at any point, were to jump between two particles and change even just two degrees of temperature rather than one, and it happens to be at the point if it weren’t for the jump the constants, when graphed, would meet, then this theorem would not be true. Of course, this is probably not the most likely circumstance, however it means that there is not a complete, 100% chance that two antipodes have even just the same temperature.

Aight, gonna play this little game with the languages I know, let's take 85 :
French :
Quatre Vingt Cinq (15) - Quinze (6) - Six (3) - Trois (5) - Cinq (4) - Quatre (6) - Six (3)... Seems like it loops between 6, 3, 5 and 4.
German :
Fünfundachtzig (14) - Vierzehn (8) - Acht (4) - Vier (4) - Vier (4)... Seems like it's the same as English. In fact, up to 10, only 6 and 7 aren't spelled with 4 letters.
Japanese (Kana) :
はちじゅうご(5) - ご (1) - いち (2) - に (1) - いち (2) ... So in kana, Japanese seems to orbit around 1 and 2... funny but what about something readable by occidentals ?
Japanese (Hepburn Romanization) :
Hachijyuugo (11) - Jyuuichi (8) - Hachi (5) - Go (2) - Ni (2) - Ni (2)... here 2 would be a fixed point.

If you want to mix up your coffee with a spoon, just dip it in, take it out with coffee in it, and then pour the coffee in the spoon back into the cup. The coffee that was in the spoon and the coffee that was barely not in the spoon don't end up next to each other, so it's not continuous and the theorem doesn't apply. You can also mix coffee with a tube if you put your finger on the end and lift some coffee out of the cup, which is why stirrers aren't solid.

In Swedish, 3 is the cosmic number, as most our words for numbers are three (Ett, Två, Tre, Fem, Sex, Sju, Nio, Tio), so most our larger numbers end in 3:
9'564 Niotusenfemhundrasextiofyra -> 27 tjugiosju -> 9 nio -> 3 tre
2'873'488 Tvåmiljoner åttahundrasjuttiotretusen fyrahundraåttioåtta -> 55 femtiofem -> 9 nio -> 3 tre and so on and so forth.
Four (fyra) is also a cosmic number, but it's pretty difficult to get to, as only 4, 8, 11 and 12 have four letters (fyra, åtta, elva, tolv).

Here's python code to compute the approximate square root described!

from random import *
from math import *
x = float(raw_input("enter a positive number to iterate towards the sqrt:"))
margin = float(raw_input("enter a margin of error (more accurate = slower!):"))
a = -1
b = 1
it = 0
while abs(float(a) - float(b)) > margin:
a = uniform(b,x)
b = float(x)/a
it += 1
print("a:{}".format(a))
print("b:{}".format(b))
print("iterations:{}".format(it))

It's impossible for infinities to be different sizes, because they are all infinite.  Even if one contains a more diverse collection of numbers, that doesn't make it larger.  That makes it "slower" as in, were you going to count upward within the parameters of the infinity you set, you would get to higher numbers more slowly.  But an infinity isn't constrained by time.  It's never ending.  Which means, whether your infinity has all real numbers, or just all integers, both of them will be counting forever.  The same size.

I am Brazilian and when I learned about the trick of finding 4 in the names of the numbers, I decided to try and found something a bit bizarre:
I'll write the numbers and their names in Portuguese, and check it out - it is strange

I'll start with 10
10
DEZ
3
TRES
4
QUATRO
6
SEIS
4
QUATRO
6
SEIS
4
QUATRO

Got it? It tries to lock on 4, but due the way numbers are written in PT, it simply doesn't work, creating an oscillation between 6 and 4 - but it tries to stay on 4, but 4 has 6 letters and this is what screws up everything.
I believer that similar things occur in other languages, but what I think is more strange is the fact of - no matter which language or how the numbers are called - it always tries to lock on 4. Why is there a pattern if human language doesn't have such a pattern? Or has it?

Michael also forgot to mention that the "four" thing doesn't apply to every single language, since some languages will have loops, while other languages can have numbers that aren't 4.

Endless loop:
In Spanish and Portuguese you'll be looping between 4 and 6 (cuatro/quatro and seis)
In Catalan you'll be looping between 3, 4 and 6 in that order (tres, quatre and sis)
In Japanese, if you only count the hiragana writing, you'll be looping between 1 and 2 (いち and に)
In Korean you'll be looping between 1 and 2 (하나 and 둘)
In French you'll be looping between 4, 6, 3 and 5 in that order (quatre, six, trois and cinq)
In Indonesian you'll be looping between 4 and 5 (empat and lima)
In Russian you'll be looping between 4, 6 and 5 in that order (четыре, шесть and пять)
In Polish you'll be looping between 6, 5 and 4 in that order (sześć, pięć and cztery)
In Icelandic you'll be looping between 3, 4 and 6 in that order (þrír, fjórir and sex)
In Greek you'll be looping between 4 and 7 (τέσσερα and επτά)
In Arabic you'll be looping between 4 and 5 (أربعة and خمسة)
In Hindi you'll be looping between 1 and 2 (एक and दो)
In Hebrew you'll be looping between 3 and 5 (שְׁלוֹשָׁה and חָמֵשׁ)
In Latin you'll be looping between 4 and 8, or between 3 and 6 (quattuor and octo) (tribus and sex)

You don't end up stuck on 4:
In Finnish you'll be stuck on 5 (viisi)
In Thai you'll be stuck on 3 (สาม)
In Italian you'll be stuck on 3 (tre)
In Chinese you'll be stuck on 1 (一)

Multiple numbers:
In Danish and Norwegian you can be stuck on 2, 3 or 4 (to, tre or fire)
In Swedish you can be stuck on 3 or 4 (tre or fyra)
In Croatian you can be stuck on 3, or be looping between 4 and 6 (tri) (četiri and šest)
In Esperanto you can be stuck on 2, 3 or 4 (du, tri or kvar)
In Lithuanian you can be stuck on 2 or 7, or be looping between 4 and 6 (du or septyni) (keturi and šeši)
In Turkish you can be stuck on 4, or be looping between 2 and 3 (dört) (iki and üç)

Languages that actually do end up stuck on 4:
In English this trick works (four) you don't say
In German, Afrikaans and Dutch this trick works (vier)
In Filipino this trick works (apat)

I haven't bothered to check more languages, I got tired.

The fixed point coffee mug thing is wrong.
just give every molecule a number from 1 to n, then move every molecule x to the position of the molecule x+1. (1 -> 2, 2 -> 3, ... n -> 1). Obviously no molecule will stay at the same point this way.
I think the problem is, that the points on a map are related to each other. For example let point A be adjacent to point B. This relation will always stay, even if you zoom in or out, turn the map or whatever. But the molecules of the coffee are completely independent, you can give them a complete new order as you like.

In Russian, the number thing where all of the numbers converge at a particular point, does something more interesting. It has two end points and an end loop. The Russian name for 3 is три (tree) and the name for 11 is одиннадцать (ah-DEEN-nad-tsat'). Only three numbers end at three, 2, 3, and 100, and they get there in one step. A lot of other numbers end at 11, such as 16, 22, 23, and many more. But the vast majority of Russian numbers end in a loop that goes 6->5->4->6->5... The names are шесть (6, shyest'), пять (5, pyat'), and четыре (4, chet-ir-ye).

An well designed elevator remember when you pushed that button, so pressing again is useless (idempotent). In practice, some elevators will close the door faster while servicing a different floor when pressing the button on any other floor.

The worst are some old relay based elevator which literally forget that you pushed the button. Microprocessor based elevator are less likely to have such bugs, but it is still possible that some poorly written firmware suffer race condition.

In Norway, there are THREE cosmic numbers. 2, 3, and 4. In Norwegian, "Two" is "To", "Three" is "Tre", and "Four" is "Fire". So to has 2 letters, and it goes on forever, and the same with tre, and fire. That's some strange things.

'femtifire' (54/fiftyfour in norwegian) goes to 'ni' (9/nine) which goes to 'to' (2/two). And there it goes forever.

'firehundreogsekstifiretusensekshundreogsekstiåtte' (464,668/fourhundredandsixtyfourthousandsixhundredandsixtyeight) which goes to 'førtini' (49/fourtynine) which goes to 'sju/syv' (7/seven) which goes to 'tre' (3/three). And there it goes forever.

'seksti' (60/sixty) which goes to 'seks' (6/six) which goes to 'fire' (4/four). And there it goes forever.

So those were the three cosmic numbers in Norwegian.

That example has a limit to how much you decrease it in size, if you make the overlapping piece of paper smaller then 1 square of the original it becomes quite easy. Hence now that you are only the size of 1 piece you only have one color overlapping, but if you were to flip the paper and put it on the boundary of one of its neighbors and make sure that the same corresponding boundary in the smaller paper lines up with the boundary of the larger piece, you will see it miraculously never light up at all.

This is because now that you are only over 2 different colors you only need to worry about those 2 colors, and by making sure that all of color a is in the background color B and that all of color b is in all of background color A, the problem is avoided.

Thinking about the "attractive nine" fixed point, you can do this trick with any number to find if it is divisible by something, just write the number out in a bass of one more than the factor you are checking. For example, I could check if sixteen is divisible by eight (it is, of course) by writing it in base nine: 17, or one nine and seven ones. 1+7=8, which is divisible by eight, so sixteen is divisible by eight. This is much more useful, especially with small numbers, for checking whether something is divisible by eight than the rule of "if the last three digits are divisible by eight, then the number is divisible by eight."

720->270
900->090

The problem with antipodal points is more of a problem with how we logically apply mathematics. Clearly, two antipodal points that have no connection other than the same body as one another wouldn't necessarily have to have anything to do with one another.

And I think this is where we get into problems with continuous numbers, because you can come up with a million absurd statements similar where, if you assume that distance, time, temperature, and the like are thought of as continuous curves.

You don't even need antipodal points. You can say that two points within your house must be exactly the same temperature and pressure as one another as well.

This is why each measurement should be seen as its own individual reading with a certain margin of error attached. Graphing such measurements can give useful information about cause, effect or correlation if nothing else, but once you start applying functional curves to reality, that's when you run into absurdity.

My physics teacher used the same fixed point theorem to prove that, if sitting outside drinking a beer, you get annoyed by the fact your four-legged table is wobbling, then you can just turn it around its middle point and you'll always find a position of stability.
Proof is: consider the (admitedly continuous) surface of the floor, and imagine you glue three table legs to it. The fourth is then sticking up, at a positive altitude. Then turn the table 90°, while letting the same three legs glued to the floor. The fourth leg is now at a negative altitude (obviously that's just a thought experiment). That means that at some point during the 90° revolution, it passed at altitude 0...
There you go, next time you'll enjoy your beer in the best condition, you're welcome! :)

3 pounds mixed apples (such as Granny Smith, Gala and McIntosh)
2/3 cup granulated sugar
2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice
6 tablespoons unsalted butter
1 tablespoon all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting
3/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon
1/8 teaspoon salt
2 disks dough for Basic Crust
1 large egg, beaten
Coarse sugar, for sprinkling

Peel and core the apples; slice 1/4 inch thick. Toss with the granulated sugar and lemon juice. Heat 4 tablespoons butter in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the apples and cook, stirring, until tender, about 10 minutes. Stir in the flour, cinnamon and salt; cook until thickened, 1 more minute. Let cool.

Roll out 1 disk of dough into a 12-inch round on a floured surface; ease into a 9-inch pie plate. Add the apples, mounding them slightly in the center, and dot with the remaining 2 tablespoons butter. Roll out the remaining dough into a 12-inch round. Lay it over the filling; press the edges of the crusts together, then fold the overhang under itself and crimp to seal. Brush with the beaten egg and sprinkle with coarse sugar. Cut a few slits in the top crust. Chill 1 hour.

Place a baking sheet on the lowest oven rack and preheat to 425 degrees F for 30 minutes. Place the pie on the hot baking sheet; lower the temperature to 375 degrees F. Bake until golden, 1 hour to 1 hour, 10 minutes. (Cover the edges with foil if they brown too quickly.) Cool on a rack

"At any given moment, there must be at least one pair of points on Earth's surface, that are diametrically opposite one another, but nonetheless have the same temperature and atmospheric pressure."
That statement made in the video (9:38) is, in fact, almost always FALSE.

Here's why:
While it is demonstrably true that at least one pair of points diametrically opposed on Earth's surface (antipodes) must have the same temperature, and it is demonstrably true that at least one pair of antipodes must have the same atmospheric pressure... what is not demonstrably true is that the antipodes that have the same temperature also has the same atmospheric pressure, or vice versa. Atmospheric pressure and temperature are NOT functionally dependent upon one another.

What is true is:
There are always two antipodes where temperature are the same, and there are always two antipodes where pressure are the same, but they are not necessarily the same pair of antipodes.... the statement in the video was that there is always a pair of antipodes where temperature AND pressure are the same.

Vsause is wrong here, you CAN have earth not have at least two antipodal points on the earth where a the atmospheric pressure and temperature is different, well, In fact, I don't think there ever will, or has been one point that is exactly the same, well at least not until the heat death of the universe.

tldr; Temperature jumps from atom to atom, ALWAYS, so there will ALWAYS be JUMPS in the graph he showed, meaning it won't pass through each other when it flips, it will JUMP PAST each other.

To explain why he's wrong. Lets look at temperature, the fact that the temperate EVER changes anywhere on earth proves that there was a jump in temperature. If it is 1 degrees on point A and 2 on point B, then somewhere, between point A and B, there was a jump in temperature, unless point A and B are an INFINITE distance away, which is not the case when it comes to earth. The only way for a continues string of variables along a sphere to be perfectly containing of every single inbetween temperature of 1 and 2 is for either for every point on the sphere to be the same temperature already, or for the sphere to be infinitely large.


As you may have seen him explain on his "how to count past infinity" video, there are Infinite digits between 1 and 2, therefore Infinite possible temperatures, there fore on earth there is always a point where when temperature changes, there is a jump in temperature change. A JUMP, not a incline, there fore the two points you flipped can JUMP at any point and will technically jump at EVERY SINGLE point.


The same is for atmospheric pressure, there will always be JUMPS in pressure, making his little explanation wrong.


If it were a sphere with infinite locations in a theoretical world, maybe. but on earth, it's just 100% incorrect to make that assumption.


Now someone might go ahead and say ""There are infinite points, which are infinitely small, between point A and point B, therefore it could change at a rate instead of jumps"", which is wrong, because temperature varies ATOM to ATOM, and JUMPS ATOM to ATOM, so, in this universe. Vsause is incorrect. Temperature JUMPS atom to atom, not changes like his little chart showed.

Hello, for no reason in particular I wanted to ask anyone who is good at probability and numbers to disprove my logic stating that "infinite" is impossible. I just wanted someone to disprove this because I think a lot, keep getting stuck on this point and no one seems to want to listen to me.

Infinite has an intrinsic probability. For example if a light has two settings (on, off) that means there is a 1 in 2 chance it is on and 1 in 2 chance it is off. 0.5 probability. If there are two lights with two settings there are one in four chances the first will be on and the second off. 0.25 probability. If there are infinite lights and infinite settings that means there is a 1 over 1 chance they are all on. 1 probability. This doesn't seem to make sense as there is 100% chance they are both all on and all off. You could also say it like this. If there are infinite universes there is 100% chance there is one that you can travel to all universes from and 100% chance there is a universe that cannot be traveled to even though they cannot logically coexist.

Now intelligent people and people who think they are intelligent have I found something, have done something illogical in my reasoning or is there some science/mathematics that has already taken this into account. Bah. That theorum(in regards to Earth) assumes that you can't go from one point to another without the temperature/pressure raising/dropping in spikes. In other words: the temperature in point A and the temperature in point B drops 2 degrees, not 1. If you use exact points on the graph, instead of line, then no, this theory just falls apart. In fact, the further your degree of accuracy goes, the more unlikely it is that you will ever see two opposite points on earth with the same temperature, or the same pressure.

This theory for Earth only holds if you graph using a straight line instead of pinpoint accuracy.
Example: Point A was 13.659 degrees on both sides of the Earth, but no matter what, there was no Point B that was 13.659c, 13.658c, or 13.660c, simply because the temperature of the very next atom nearby on at least one side was 13.661c, while the other side was 13.657c.
Or, the very next atom was .000000000000000000001m to the left/right/up/down of it's counterpart.
Or, there was no atom at all to counterpoint, just the vacuum between loosely packed atoms, which is more likely if the surface is water.

The theory for the coffee cup is also misleading: there are infinitely more places for atoms of coffee to exist than there are atoms in the cup. Even by a degree of movement as small as the fraction of a fraction of an electron's quark, the chance that EVERY ATOM will be somewhere new and not occupying any previously existing place EXACTLY (the most exact atom could still be 1 degree tilted on the z axis differently than before mixing) is infinitesimal.

The theory CAN be true for these examples, simply due to probability, or by looseness of definition. But the more exact you make your definitions, the less likely it will occur, if ever.

The fixed point theory in a coffee mug does not work, since you can move the coffee out of its place and usually you do. If you use honey or another dense fluid instead, it becomes visually clear. The hole you leave behind the spoon testifies that you have moved the fluid out of its space. If instead you would move the spoon slowly, the theory may apply, because you are merely moving an object in the liquid than stirring it.

Imagine that I have a car filled with balloons. This car has a lemniscate (the sideways 8 that represents infinity) on the licence plate. The number of balloons in that car cannot be counted. It is literally impossible to count them. One might come along and say "Well, they all fit in one car. Imagine if we changed that license plate to a different symbol and put a zero beside it. Now imagine if you had two cars (with the same symbol plus 1), or three, or an uncountable number of them. And what if the uncountable number of them is on a car carrier? And there are multiple car carriers?" To which I would reply "You can't have more than one car full of them because the ones in the car already can't be counted. Another car full of the same number can't exist, because this one already contains all of the balloons that there can be in a car."

We already have a variable for infinity (the aforementioned sideways 8), which you can't do anything with because it's infinite. Changing the variable, then adding to that variable, is impossible, because the first variable by necessity must already contain every countable number. That would have to include aleph 1, aleph 2, etc. because they can be counted.

I'm kinda surprised he didn't also mention Kaprekar's constant (6174). This number is neat. Here's how it works:

1. Take any 4 digit number that isn't just 4 identical numbers (for example, 9999 won't work). Let's use 8593.
2. Reorder the numbers from largest to smallest - 9853.
3. Reorder the numbers from smallest to largest - 3589.
4. Subtract the number in step 3 from the number in step 2. 9853-3589 = 6264
5. Repeat steps 2-4 with the same number and record the result:
5a. 6642-2466 = 4176
5b. 7641-1467 = 6174
5c. 7641-1467 = 6174

You'll notice that no matter which 4 digits you choose, as long as they're not all the same digit, you'll eventually reach 6174 and it will keep looping forever. This is Kaprekar's constant.

Pretty neat, huh?

For the glowing pixels, what if you did this:
Shrink it so it is less than the size of one pixel. Rotate it 180 degrees, and line up the edge between, say, the the dark grey and its column and light grey and its column (in the shrunken version) with the line between the light grey pixel and dark grey pixel. The light grey and its column will be completely within the dark grey box, and the dark grey and it's column (along with the rest of the columns) will be in the light gray box.

Of course, this doesn't disprove your actual point since a point on the boundary between the light and dark grey will still be in the same spot, but no part of any pixel will be lit up.

1, 3, 6, 9:
1 photon with
3 components (Electrical, Magnetic, Direction) all basically 90 degrees from each other,
each component having an oscillation of energy,
maximum in one direction, neutral, maximum in the other direction.

So:
Electrical : max in one direction, neutral, max in the other direction;
Magnetic : max in one direction, neutral, max in the other direction;
Direction : max in one direction, neutral, max in the other direction.
(The direction of a stationary photon is a pulse. It goes to it's central core area, then flips and goes to it's max extension area, then flips, etc, etc, etc);

6 maximum most reactive positions with
9 total reactive positions (neutrals included).
Hence 1, 3, 6, 9 being very prominent numbers in our math systems.

And, if it were taken further: 1 + 3 + 6 + 9 = 19
1 + 9 = 10
1 + 0 = 1, back to the 1 photon.

I don't think you get stuck at four because it's the only number spelled with the same number of letters it represents... It's more likely you get stuck there because the numbers around it create a funnel that always leads to 4. Three (5) -> Five (4) -> Four (4), or Six (3) -> Three (5) -> Five (4)  -> Four (4). I tried this out with Spanish and it doesn't work, because the numbers surrounding it's only number Cinco (5) are Cuatro (6) and Seis (4). So if you take Veintidos (9) -> Nueve (5) -> Cinco (5) it works. But if you use Veintitres (10) -> Diez (4) -> Cuatro (6) -> Seis (4) -> Cuatro (6) -> Seis (4), you get stuck in an endless loop and never land on Cinco. I'm assuming this same "flaw" could be repeated in another language?

"It's the only number in the english language spelled with the same number of letters as the quantity it represents." ... Well, no. That's not true. Not entirely anyway. For example, many numbers have several names, such as "twelve" and "dozen" or "zero" and "aught". So, bearing that in mind, I submit this: "Sextet". It is, technically, a number. Or if you want the "a" that precedes included, you can use "a septet". They're numbers in exactly as much as "six" or "seven" are, because they are English words conveying the same mathematical value. All the words for numbers that we use became more or less common in mathematics arbitrarily. So, yeah. There are a few more.

Likewise, if you took the layers of coffee and rearranged them so that the layers that used to be 12345 are now 54132, there would be none of the coffee back where it originally was.

Sorry, but the Borsuk-Ulam theorem isn't necessarily correct.  Just because the data crosses doesn't mean that there is data at the point where it crosses.  For example, the data crosses at 50.3 degrees.  However there is no place on earth where both antipodes are 50.3.  There may be one at 50.2 and the other side is at 50.4, and vice versa and the data will cross, however there will be no point that satisfies the requirements.

I found something cool by accident in math class one day.

When I take the number 7 and multiply it with n where n = 0 to 9 and write the result down as two digits
i.e. 00
07
14 .... etc
Then add the two digits together to make 10 single digits I end up with. 075 418 6429
Where I'm from, that's a working phone number. It doesn't work with any other number, only 7.
So after class I called the number, out of curiosity.
A recording played saying that my phone was now blocked and that I would have to call my service provider to get it working again.
But that was just a prank and my phone still worked fine. I didn't really know what the odds were that so many people arrived at this number that someone had this prank set in place. Still pretty neat though.

The example with stirring the coffee doesn't work:
If you move the spoon right through the centre you'll move some amount of coffee towards the side of the cup. Upon "hitting" the boundaries, some part of the coffee will move to the left and some to the right side of the cup, meaning you essentially "cut" some of the coffee. Therefore stirring (unless stirring just means moving the spoon in a circle) is not a continuous function.

The coffee stirring is a bad example, because the molecules can effectively reposition themselves in the same way the cutting and pasting example does. Imagine all of the molecules were rotated around the center by 90 degrees. None of them would be in their original locations except for the middle column of molecules. if you then took the spoon and dragged it across the diameter, the middle ones would have been moved out of their original position, and it's entirely possible for none of the other molecules to have gone back to their original position, because you've effectively cut the relationship. The math and theory is still correct, but stirring coffee is not a correct example because it falls into one of the caveat conditions of the mathematical theory.

Noting that four is the only fixed point in terms of counting the letters that spell it (meaning that applying that operation recursively will loop forever) doesn't in and of itself guarantee that you'd end up at four regardless of your starting point. For example, 0 and 1 are fixed points of exponentiation, but you don't end up in an infinite loop of 0 or 1 when you repeatedly square a number.

It's possible that there's a non-looping infinite sequence of integers (or, more likely an infinite number of families of infinite sequences) that you could enter instead. Of course, maybe this has been proven not to happen, but it's possible in principle.

First, thank you for these awesome videos, you have a unique way of making us, viewers, think about new things and more impotently ordinary things in new ways.
However the coffee mixing is not entirely accurate, I think. Actually coffee is a liquid, which means that it can be transformed in a non continuous way, molecules in the coffee are free to move away from each other allowing other molecules to fill up the space. If you imagine a connected ball of coffee initially inside the coffee filled mug, you can split it with a spoon and put one half away from the other, resulting in your transformation function having a non connected image of a connected set, thus the function is not continuous and the fixed point theorem doesn't apply.

Firstly love your work it gets me thinking every time I watch a video. In a way the error Im pointing out got me thinking even more than usual.
Your statement about mixing coffee is incorrect. Once you put the object inside of the coffee you have changed its bounds (the coffee is displaced up the cup) and created a hole where the spoon is filling. Then you also have to consider as a liquid you can by mixing the coffee "cut and glue" the component molecule to new ones as you mix it around as they are all similarly attracted to each other. This is how the coffee can flow around the spoon.
If your statement held true for mixing liquids then fluid mechanics would be a lot similar than it is.

if you think you've measured two points of equal pressure and temperature on the earth, you simply haven't measured precisely enough. The lighting up square analogy falls apart:
the theorem only works with continuous space, not with pixels that have fixed boundaries.
if you just made it 6x6 blocks and rotated it, not a single field would light up.


And the mixing isn't true either.
Simplify it - lets say you have just 2 balls in the cup - move them a bit around - it is very very unlikely that either of them goes back to its exact original position.
With liquids you of course have a couple billion times more atoms to consider, so higher chance due to that, but you also have a vastly bigger possibility realm.
if it wasn't due to uncertainty, you could even go as far as to say that not a single particle would ever go back to any of its previously held positions.

A channel with 10M+ subscribers should be more careful about the accuracy of what they publish, especially one which is trying to teach people something.
This video is so riddled with errors I hardly know where to begin.
Let me take the Borsuk-Ulam theorem. In order for it to be true, both temperature and pressure must vary continuously over the surface of the earth, but neither do. Regions of different temperatures and pressures are separated by boundary layers that meteorologists call fronts. Since the assumptions of the theorem are violated, the application of the theorem is invalid.
I knew you were going to hit one of my pet peeves the moment you mentioned infinity. Aleph Null is not a number. No operations valid for numbers are defined for it, not even equality. Furthermore, any infinite sequence at n terms is different from the infinite sequence less one term at n terms by the difference between the first and nth terms, for any and all n, so they are only equal when the first and nth are equal. In a monotonically decreasing sequence, this is never true. So Aleph subscript infinite aleph is not equal to Aleph subscript [infinite less one|warning: this expression is undefined, too] aleph for both reasons.
The coffee stirring example is wrong for the same reason as the Borsuk-Ulam example, coffee is not continuous. I give you credit for noting that coffee isn't continuous, but a collection of particles. But I give you failing marks for continuing. A theorem which isn't true for discontinuities isn't true. There is no such thing in logic as almost true.
But for the sake of argument, let's pretend coffee is a continuous substance. Putting the spoon in it is a discontinuous deformation. So is taking the spoon out. If some of the coffee sticks to the spoon when you take it out, its a cut. If a drop of that liquid falls off the spoon back into the coffee, that's a paste. And let's not forget the water vapor that escaped while you were stirring.

Hi Vsauce, you suggest that there are always antipodal points on Earth with equal temperature and equal pressure. This seems true only in the case that an isotherm or isobar happens to have precisely corresponding antipodes to itself, allowing the Borsuk-Ulam Theorem to be used again. I do not see how math would prove this true with two continuous variables considered independently the way you described. It could just be a rare coincidence. However with that argument, it then seems highly unlikely, and can be conceivably false. I watched the other videos on the Borsuk-Ulam Theorem from the links in the dooblydoo of your video and I am still not convinced of the proof method described. However, if elevation change is possible, then any path can be isobaric by changing the elevation. There can then be a forced set of isobaric antipodes to work with, and the statement becomes true. Still, it is difficult to technically discuss temperature and pressure separately because they are related by the ideal gas law.

The temperature in the world does not decrease/increase at equal pace.. thus it doesnt need to be the same since they may never cross paths from the get go. Since the points travel on different sides, and not the same side (as the graph that was displayed), they dont need to travel across the same temperature curv as the other point. Lets say one point goes from europe (5 degrees)  to the americas (50 degrees) on one side, across the atlantic, and the other goes from the americas to europe across the pacific; the pacific side may go from 50 degrees to 20 during the first 100 miles, and then from 20 to 30, and then from 30 to 10, and then in the end from 10 going slowly til 5 when reaching europe. The other side, goes from 5 degrees to minus 10 and then to 20 and then to 15 and so on.. the differences would be different at different times and places, if this world had two sides that were similar to each other then this theory would hold, but not when we have a world that is a sphere of unique sides.  It is misleading to show a 2d graph of a 3d situation in this way.

I wonder if similar idempotent chains exist in other languages. With Japanese it depends how you write the number. Hiragana, romaji or kanji. Or katakana, I suppose, but why use those for numbers? Anyway, with kanji, a longer number in terms of characters within the Arabic numeral system that we use in English won't necessarily increase the number of kanji, or if it does, not by much. For example, 10000, man, has one character in kanji, 100,000, jiu-man would use two, as would 1000,000, hyaku-man. But then after 10,000,000, sen-man we reach the next order and a new, singular kanji because the Japanese numbering convention is based around systems of ten thousand. A more complex number, however, would use more kanji. 10,003, for example, is man-san, which is two kanji. Then 11,283 would be man-ichi-sen-ni-hyaku-hachi-ji-san. Which would be seven or eight kanji, depending on if you include ichi (1) in reference to the number of thousnds (sen) or not. In either case, the number of kanji is lower than ten, so would itself be one kanji, which then loops. With a complex number of more than ten kanji, it would reduce to either two or three, which reduces to one, which repeats. Nothing special there; of course one loops in this instance. With hiragana and katakana, it would function a little differently. San, meaning three, consists of two characters; sa and n. Then two is ni, which is one. Ichi is two; i and chi, so it loops between one and two. Ten thousand, hyakuman consists of hi(ya), ku, ma and n. This reduces to four which is either shi or yon; which go to one and two respectively and establish the loop. Even 11,283 would do this; consisting of 14 or 15 characters, depending on if you count the ya as seperate to the hi in hyaku. It could also be 12 or 13 if ichi is omitted. Jiu-ni, jiu-san, jiu-yon and jiu-go consist of 3/4 or 5. Which enter the ichi-ni-loop. With romaji it would loop at san or ni.

Man, I am sooo tired of hearing about the Borsuk-Ulam Theorem ;-)

your algorithm for recursive alephs is incorrect.

Because the subscript of every aleph (_) is the main input/variable, that means that it would have to end on the right/bottom-most, and not on the left/top-most script. for it to end on the right would mean that a countably infinite number of steps had to be taken to reach an aleph with a countable subscript (aleph [with no subscript] by itself does not denote any particular infinity), which had to be the input in the first place for the recursive algorithm. the algorithm's construction would have to end in the first place to receive the input, so it wouldn't be endless and thus it couldn't be countably infinite number of infinities.

your algorithm and reasoning reminds me of the colloquial proof for .999... = 1, which is that if you take .9 from .999... and .9 from 1 and multiply both sides by ten, you get .999... = 1. this is incorrect. you cannot take .9 from .999... because subtraction/arithmetic starts from the lowest decimal place, and you cannot get to the lowest decimal place with .999... (.999... doesn't end with a digit that is 9; it doesn't go 999... ...9, that would be an incorrect construction of a number - it doesn't end).
the rigorous proof is by geometric series, the value of sum(rx10^-n, n to infinity) = 1/(1-r) for r=.9 = 1, but its construction is a countably infinite series of decimal places all equal to nine and it doesn't end, thus .999...

you have to start with a finite input and finite construction, and your algorithm isn't a finite construction.

I learned that formula in one of my engineering classes a couple days ago. It's called Newton's Method. If you want to find the point where two lines intersect you repeatedly use the formula x-(f(x)/f`(x)) until the answer is continuous
Where:
x=Initial guess and subsequent answers
f(x)=Your original formula
f`(x)=The derivative of the formula

If you wanted to find sqrt(16), then you would have y=sqrt(16). However, for the formula to work, your function must be equal to 0. It has to be 0 because the formula is meant to find where the line tangent to the specified point crosses the x-axis. So we get y^2-16=0. So now f(x)=x^2-16. Plugging in these values to the formula we get:
g(x)=x-((x^2-16)/2x)
You can simplify this to get:
g(x)=(x+(16/x))/2
Where 16 is the number you want to find the square root of.

If you plug in any value and then plug the answer into the formula again, the answer will get closer and closer to the value you need. So if we use 3, we'll get the following answers:
g(3)=4.167
g(4.16666666667)=4.003
g(4.00333333333)=4.00000138773
g(4.00000138773)=4
g(4)=4

Not sure I agree with the coffee stirring example. Surely it is possible for each molecule to be in a different position after stirring. A simple counter example is if the molecules are numbered 1 to N, then molecule 1 ends up where molecule 2 was, molecule 2 ends up where molecule 3 was ... molecule N ends up where molecule 1 was. Stirring is not a continuous transformation because the distance between molecules in the 'after' state does not have to approach zero if the distance between the molecules in the 'before' state did approach zero.

Talking about fixed points and iterations, the banach fixpoint theorem is interesting (not sure if that's what it is called in english). If you have an infinite domain with a norm (e.g. euclidean space) and a continuous transformation of that domain into itself, which is also a contraction, then this contraction has exactly one fixed point. Any starting point will converge to that fixed point when the transformation is applied repeatedly. The shown square root algorithm is basically that, a continuous contraction of the (positive) real numbers onto themselves. That the square root is a fixed point is trivial to see. One only has to show that it is a contraction to conclude, that the algorithm always works.

Coffee and milk do mix in the end because of molecular diffusion. In the absence of molecular diffusion, one will have infinitely thin bands (upto molecular widths if stirred for enough time). The time at which the "mixing" occurs is classically defined as the mixing time (the lengthscale at which the stirring and diffusion are of comparable orders is defined as the Batchelor scale - named after the renowned fluid dynamicist G K Batchelor).

3:45 I think I see a way to manipulate the checkerboard. First shrink the board so it's smaller than 1 colored square of the larger board then rotate 180. Let's look at the green on the first column, third row and its adjacent yellowish color. Align the smaller board so that the border between the yellow and green is shared, but the green overlaps the yellow and vice versa. Since there are no other colors involved, the smaller board can only share a color with the green or yellow, but you've perfectly overlapped the smaller green to the larger yellow and vice versa.

Did anyone notice the mistake at 3:42?

He says: "You cannot get every pixel to be outside its original square unless you cut or move the WHOLE shape outside the space it used to fill."

But you don't need to move the WHOLE shape out to get rid of all glowing parts, you can leave the right side of the small square overlapping with the left side of the big square and already get no glowing parts.

So the correct statement should be: "You cannot get every pixel to be outside its original square unless you cut or move the shape SUCH THAT AT LEAST A PART OF IT IS outside the space it used to fill".

I guess the example with the map is better explained by Banach's fixed point theorem rather than Brouwer's. At least that's the common example for Banach's fixed point theorem.
Banach's fixed point theorem states that any continuous mapping that makes distances between points smaller (more precisely, there is some positive number less than one such that the distance between any two mapped points is at most that number times the distance between the original points) has exactly one fixed point. This does not require boundedness or no holes, just a nonempty complete metric space.
So actually, even when the map is crumbled up or folded, there will be no more than one point lying on the point it represents.

The fixed point theorem appears in construction of a class of fractals named IFS (Iterated Function Systems). These fractals are described by a set of transformations leading to a fixed point, which is the fractal itself. This has been used in fractal image compression since we keep only small number of transformations and can use any starting image at any resolution and always end up with the target (decoded) image after few iterations.

The JPEG lossy image compression, for example, is designed to be idempotent, hence if you recompress an already compressed image (with same quality settings), no information is loss, the quality will stay the same.

Image descriptors in computer vision are often designed to be invariant to various geometric transformations, hence images can be matched and aligned to each other regardless on how they are moved, rotated or zoomed.

No, actually, the molecules in the coffee will never be where they are before; coffee is a liquid, the molecules are always moving, they are not stationary. As such, although molecules may cross positions they've crossed before, they cannot actually be AT the position they've been AT before, because they've never been stationary at a position. Unless you freeze coffee, the molecules will always be moving.

And strictly speaking, the same goes for the frozen coffee; unless you reach absolute zero Kelvin; even molecules in a solid are vibrating around a point.

Here's an acceleration anomaly I have discovered, but don't have an explanation for. When an object, such as a spacecraft, constantly accelerates in a vacuum, after exactly two hours it's speed in kilometers or miles per hour always equals the distance it has traveled or displaced in those units. Example: if a spacecraft accelerates at one g (9.85 meters per second squared) after two hours it will reach a speed of 250,000 kilometers per hour at a distance of 250,000 kilometers. This ratio holds true whatever the acceleration rate is. At 10 g (98.5 meters per second squared) after two hours the ship is traveling at 2.5 million kph at a distance of 2.5 million kms. Anyone know why?

I am not convinced that the stirring of coffee is analogous to a continuous transformation. The feature that distinguishes continuous transformations from the other types of transformations is that any two points that are neighbors before the transformation will remain neighbors during and after the transformation. (That's why cut/paste is not allowed.)

The stirring of a liquid seems to break this rule. While there is likely groupings of molecules, that are still together after stirring, I don't see a reason to assume that every molecule will remain in proximity to its original neighbors - and so the theorem does not apply.

The explanation at the end about FOUR isn't really complete. Yes, any number this function is applied to enough times will converge to FOUR, but the fact that FOUR is the only number in English spelled with as much letters as the value it represents does not give you this yet.

Suppose we have a dialect of English where 5 is spelled out as FIV. If we start with SIX, we get THREE, which goes to FIV, which goes to THREE, and so on.

Any number in regular English converges to FOUR because it is the only LOOP (in this case of length 1).

So I thought about something interesting; you know how when playing an rpg of somekind you can land a critical action by doing something, wither you hitting an enemy or baking a cake, you can sometimes get an exceptionally good outcome. And I thought about if this could apply to real life, and it does. If you press the elevator call button right before if coincidentally reaches the floor you just called it to that would be a critical action. Or if you were cutting a watermelon and you go clean through with no resistance, that is a critical action. And like in a game you can force some criticals to happen, like if you kiccked a ball right dead in the center it will receive the most energy and fly the straightest, or if you hit the cue ball in billiards and knock all the other balls into the pockets, or sing a note at just the right frequency to break a glass. This fact changes nothing, and it is unlikely that you will every critical at amazon and you next shipment will be free, but I think it's interesting that you can be so lucky or skilled to have a critically successful action

Let's try that 4 stuff in another languaje (spanish in this case).

Ok, first of all, cuatro (four in spanish) has 6 letters, seis (six in spanish) has 4 letters. So we just have started an endless cicle with the english mistical number. We can get stuck in the same cicle with the number ocho (8), because it also has cuatro letters, and cuatro has seis letters and so on. The same with tres (3), and with uno (1, and uno has 3 letters), and with dos (2, the same as one), and others.

Let's try a different number, 7: siete has five letters and cinco (5) has 5 letters also. Nueve (9) also has 5 numbers, so right now we know that in sanish there can be two different cicles.

Let's try a bigger number: 1 000 000, un millon has 8 letters, and then it is in the first cicle. Dos millones (2 000 000) has eleven letters, and once (11) has also four letters, so it fits in the first cicle. Let's pick something more random, let's say dos mil setecientos ochenta y cuatro (2 784)and it has 31 letters, and treinta y uno has 11 letters... also fits in the first one.

Then, looks like even when in spanish there is a number with the same amount of letters than the amount it represents looks like there is another cicle that has more elements to fit in, y eso siempre. Gracias por leer ; )

I have a special way of stirring the coffee. I take one point (1) and move it to the position of another point (2). I move the second point to the position of a third point (3) and so on, until I have moved point (n-1) to the position of point (n). I now take this last point, and move it to where point (1) used to be. Every point in the coffee is now in a new position.

About the 9 thing, ive figured out a pretty smart way to calculate Y x 9 (i did this about 7 years ago when i was 13 btw), lets say you want to calculate 73 x 9 in your head, subtract the first digit of 73 (which is 7) then subtract 1 (which will get you 65, 73-7-1 equals 65), and multiply it by 10 (650), obviously 650 isnt the correct answer, so you will need to add a number between 0 to 9 so that all 3 numbers added up equals to anything x9, in this case you would add 7, since 6+5+7 equals 18, and 18 can be divided by 9. This might look very complicated at first, but this was just a very thorough explanation of the "formula".

Awwwww... although your description of the number 25 is mathematically equivalent. It isn't how it is in a base-10 numbering system. The first digit to the left of the decimal point is the number of times that you have 10 to the zero-th power (or ones). The second position is the number of times you have ten to the first power (or tens). The third position is the number of times you have ten to the second (or hundreds)... and so forth. Each place is one power of ten larger than the previous that is closer to the decimal point. All of this is obvious as we all just know.

Thus 25 is more accurately 2 times 10 to the first power (10+10) plus 5 times 10 to the zero-th power (the zero'-th power of any base number 2 or greater is always 1... so 5 times the zero-th power of 10 is equal to 5).

Mathematically 2 ten times is the same as 10 two times. But, when trying to explain the number we know as 25, it is best to use the poper way that expresses the digits of the number in its base number notation.

A complicated subject as Fixed Points mixed in with this kind of under sight, to me, dilutes the discussion and validity for me to a consider the concept of Fixed Points. To me, if one of the foundation building blocks of a concept is fundamentally wrong, I can't proceed with what is proposed farther down the line. That was when the video ended for me.
When stirring a cup of coffee, the points can be cut, moved, and rearranged, so the theorem doesn't apply.

However, I must say that I believe you have reached a point with your videos where you seem to be moving away from what made your channel so great to begin with. All I'm asking is that you return to asking questions that are outside of the realm of normal everyday thinking, and answer them in the factual, entertaining, and truly unique way that only you can. At the pixel shape thing:
- Rotate it 180 degrees
- Resize and make it smaller until a 4x4 of the coloured squares is as big as or smaller than one of the original squares
- Move it to the top left.
- Position it in such a way that the original top left square is to the bottom right of where it used to be, and line up the borders exactly.
- The 4x4 starting from the bottom right in the original should now be fully in the top left square.
There you go, not a single square is where it used to be!

(although the intersection will not have moved...)

in Italy we have a riddle that works thanks to that part you said about 4, it is something like this (italian numbers are: uno, due, tre, quattro, cinque, sei, sette, otto, nove, dieci, undici, dodici...)
you have to enter in a room but you don't know the password so you wait and spy on others entering. First man arrives, someone says 6(sei) and he says 3 and enter, then next man arrives, someones sais 10(Dieci) and he says 5 and enters, then next man hear 12(dodici), says 6 and enter, the last man hear 8(otto), says 4 and enter, now it's your turn so you go and the man say 7(sette). What do you answer? at first anyone think of 3.5 but that's just a big coincidence cause the answer is the number of letters in the first number
ciao from Italy :)
